node.title: Younger generations pay the most in bank fees, report finds
node.description: Millennials typically pay about $16 a month in bank fees â€” eight times what the average baby boomer pays.
node.content: ["Bank customers between the ages of 18 and 41 are paying more than three times as much in ATM and overdraft fees compared to baby boomers with checking and savings accounts, according to a Bankrate survey released Tuesday.\u00a0", "Baby boomers pay an average of $2 a month in bank fees, while Gen Xers \u2014 people ages 42 to 57 \u2014 pay $4 on average, the survey found. By comparisons, the typical millennial pays $16 a month, while Gen Zers pay $19. The poll also found that younger customers are much more likely to have the type of accounts that charge monthly fees.\u00a0", "Bank overdraft fees in the U.S. have hit an all-time high. In 2021, the average fee for overdrawing your account rose to $33.58, a 22-cent increase over the past two years, according to a different Bankrate analysis. Among major U.S. cities, people living in Baltimore, Houston and Philadelphia paid the highest overdraft fees last year at more than $35. Cincinnati, Los Angeles and St. Louis paid the lowest fees at around $31.", "Big U.S. banks have generated about $9 billion annually in revenue from overdraft, ATM and other fees in recent years, according to the\u00a0Center\u00a0for Responsible Lending, or CRL. The fees have become somewhat of a\u00a0cash cow\u00a0for banks over the past 20 years, some experts have said.", "Taylor Roberson, a fintech regulation expert at CRL, said Bankrate's survey confirms what researchers have known for years about millennials baring the brunt of banking fees.\u00a0", "\"What this really means is the most financially vulnerable are being hit the most with fees,\" she told CBS MoneyWatch.\u00a0", "Although consumers can switch banks to avoid excessive fees, Roberson said a more comprehensive solution is for the U.S. to pass laws capping the charges.\u00a0", "Some federal lawmakers, including Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Massachusetts, are pushing to shrink the amount of revenue banks generate from fees, arguing the charges primarily hit\u00a0low-income customers\u00a0and households of color. In response, some banks have eliminated overdraft\u00a0or ATM fees.", "Capital One last month became the largest U.S. bank to say it would ditch overdraft and insufficient fund fees. CEO Richard Fairbank said Capital One made the move to bring \"humanity to banking.\" Ally Bank announced in June it would\u00a0no longer charge its $25 overdraft fee\u00a0for all customers, no matter what type of account they hold. Alliant, Discover and Regions have also removed overdraft fees.", "Khristopher J. Brooks is a reporter for CBS MoneyWatch covering business, consumer and financial stories that range from economic inequality and housing issues to bankruptcies and the business of sports."]
